posts.name: Guy Kawasaki
posts.cooked: When privacy declines, everything else follows, so I wrote a book explaining why and how to use Signal. It’s free on Amazon for a few days. Then goes to $4.04. Search for “Everybody Has Something to HIde” from your country’s Amazon site. When you find errors, please send to guykawasaki@gmail.com, so we can fix asap.
Nice move I’ll take a look eventually

posts.name: Rodrigo
posts.cooked: Any chance to release the book elsewhere, @GuyKawasaki? I don’t buy ebooks on Amazon for reasons similar to the ones I have to use Signal.

posts.name: Johan Vromans
posts.cooked:
Same here. Also, I do not have kindle.
Why not publish a free epub (unless you have something to hide)?
Yes, Amazon, that’s one thing. And using a gmail address is another and has nothing to do with privacy. Sorry to mention that!

I got the book and happily noticed it’s DRM-free so I could easily download it from Amazon and get it on Calibre, thank you

Since you don’t have DRM on it, I agree with others that it would be beneficial to distribute it in more ways that are more privacy-friendly than Amazon.
I’d be surprised if we see OP again. They joined, promoted their book, left an email address to be contacted at when readers find incorrect information in it. Hopefully I’m wrong.

chrononaut:

They joined, promoted their book, left an email address to be contacted at when readers find incorrect information in it.

The best proofreader is free proofreader after all.
Of course. Nothing wrong with crowdsourcing help for good things. We here all provide free beta testing services for an app

Sure, but testing free app for free is a bit different than proofing a book someone wants to sell.

At least we don’t need to pay for the privilege of being beta testers as it’s now too common in video game industry now.

posts.name: Guy Kawasaki
posts.cooked: How would you suggest I make it easy for people to report bugs?

posts.name: Guy Kawasaki
posts.cooked: Just to be clear, I’m not asking for “testing,” free or not. I’m just saying if you happen to see anything that’s wrong, just let me know, and I’ll fix it. I have paid for copyediting, proofing, and translating. Total costs of everything to complete the book is around $20,000. I don’t expect to make anything from this.

posts.name: Guy Kawasaki
posts.cooked: This is an unusual book in the sense that copyediting and proofing can catch typical writing errors. But Signal is a complex topic (encryption, meta data, etc) that typical copy editors and proof readers can’t be expected to catch. It’s been “fact checked” multiple times, but I’m a perfectionist.
@GuyKawasaki Thank you for writing the book and your podcast. Too many people are quick to moan.

posts.name: Guy Kawasaki
posts.cooked:
I don’t even know how to put DRM on it. Nor do I care to. The seemingly simple choice on how to deploy this book is complex. The target reader is probably not on this forum–it’s your friends, relatives, and associates who are not technologists. IMHO, Kindle with it’s free readers and international footprint is the best way to distribute.

I don’t want people to have to figure out Calibre, Acrobat, Preview, whatever. Nor open a Proton account to report bugs.

Consider, by contrast, the traditional path. If this book were “Signal for Dummies,” it would be another six months before it was out. The price would be $19.99. The Kindle version would be $9.99. The publisher would never let me give it away for the first five days much less price it at $4.04 after the first five days.

And with Kindle, after the first 90 days, I can give it away for another five days. Every 90 days, I can do stuff like that.

And a traditional publisher can’t revise the book until the inventory is sold. Which means it may never be revised. So when Signal offers cloud backup or polls, the book might never reflect that. With Kindle, I can revise the file, and it’s deployed in less than a day. That’s roughly 179 days faster than the best case with a traditional publisher…

FYI, the book has to be Kindle only–as opposed to on Apple Books and Kobo, etc, in order for me to be able to offer it for free and do other price promotions.

I supposed I could put the PDF “out there.” But then do we really want people downloading “a file” from who know who on their phones and computers? Not a good idea to open attachments, right?

posts.name: Guy Kawasaki
posts.cooked:
That’s a good question. I asked ChatGPT what happens when someone clicks on an epub.

When a person clicks an EPUB file, the operating system checks which app associates with that file type.

On macOS, Apple Books opens by default if installed. The book imports into the library and opens for reading.

On iPhone or iPad, the file opens in Apple Books or presents a share sheet to choose a reading app.

If no EPUB reader is installed, the system prompts the user to choose or install a compatible app.

In a browser, the file usually downloads rather than opens, unless a web-based reader handles it.

Is it a good practice to open an attachment from someone you don’t know? Do you like Apple more than Amazon for a reader app? Is it optimal for people to be told to go find a compatible epub app to open it?

posts.name: Guy Kawasaki
posts.cooked: Thanks! You are very kind. I go way back…like to CompuServe days. I’m used to how bulletin boards work. No guts, no glory!
You could use a non gmail address from a provider which is privacy conscious.

posts.name: Guy Kawasaki
posts.cooked: To report bugs? I’m not talking about whistle blowing or something like that.
And the meta data?! I wouldn’t write you. No bug report. Nothing.
